thread.name: Create Relationships with Nodes other than Peer

messages.content: that is correct as the use-case is to solve in which order the different relationships should be consumed, I think this is the same requirement <@1268206427810435166> would benefit from.

referenced_message.content: <@1082587798328061973> currently the plan is to have the priority at the profiles level, if I understand correctly you would like to have the possibility to add a priority per attribute / relationship within a profile, is that correct ?

messages.content: <@1082587798328061973> currently the plan is to have the priority at the profiles level, if I understand correctly you would like to have the possibility to add a priority per attribute / relationship within a profile, is that correct ?

after looking at this feature and doing more modelling we still think that it is lacking the possibility to have multiple relationships that we can prioritise, without having a shim-layer. By having the possibility to add priority/attributes on a relationship this would be possible.

messages.content: thanks for your reply

referenced_message.content: with this setup if you query the site object with ancestor, you can get the ntp server right upto the regional level after which you can filter things based on the priority value

messages.content:
Hi, (I'm working together with Tobbe =))
This setup will have a hard coded priority for a certain Infra Node right? We want to be able to have the same Infra Node related to different locations from where it's prioritized differently. 
For example, a Radius server in Europe should be the first priority for devices in Europe but in APAC it should have a lower priority.
We have it solved right now with a "shim" layer in between the Location/Device node and Infra Node as discussed above but some custom data on the relation would make it much easier and nicer in the GUI. Or a profile...
with this setup if you query the site object with ancestor, you can get the ntp server right upto the regional level after which you can filter things based on the priority value

Generic location is inherited by the location hierarchy (region -> country -> site). The hierarchy has parent child relationship.

e.g. site schema

```
  - name: Site
    include_in_menu: false
    namespace: Location
    description: "A site within a country."
    menu_placement: "LocationGeneric"
    human_friendly_id: ["name__value"]
    inherit_from:
      - "LocationGeneric"
    order_by:
      - "name__value"
    display_labels:
      - "name__value"
    children: "LocationRoom"
    parent: "LocationMetro"
    attributes:
      - name: alias
        kind: Text
        optional: false
        order_weight: 30
      - name: city
        kind: Text
        optional: true
        label: City
        order_weight: 1000
```

So here's an example I have (its the snipped version to simplify the schema)

Service like NTP

```---
nodes:
  - name: Ntp
    namespace: Infra
    include_in_menu: false
    label: NTP
    description: "Global NTP Services for switches"
    menu_placement: "InfraMisc"
    attributes:
      - name: ip_address
        kind: IPHost
        label: IP Address
        optional: false
      - name: vrf
        kind: Text
        optional: true
      - name: priority
        kind: Number
        default_value: 0
        order_weight: 20
    relationships:
      - name: location
        peer: LocationGeneric
        optional: false
        cardinality: one
        identifier: location__ntp```

Services like ntp etc get a relationship to generic location node

```
---
version: "1.0"
generics:
  - name: Generic # Location
    include_in_menu: false
    namespace: Location
    description: "Generic hierarchical location"
    label: "Location"
    default_filter: "name__value"
    human_friendly_id: ["name__value"]
    hierarchical: true
    attributes:
      - name: name
        kind: Text
        unique: true
        order_weight: 10
      - name: description
        kind: Text
        optional: true
        order_weight: 20
    relationships:
      - name: ntp
        peer: InfraNtp
        cardinality: many
        kind: Component
        identifier: location__ntp
```
where is the priority field set? perhaps you can share a example?

I did something similar to this by having a location generic which has all the relationship like tacacs, acl, ntp etc. with a priority field . Now each of the location hierarchy (e.g. site, region, country, continent) inherit from this location generic making sure each one of the location nodes has these relationships. 

Then I use the ancestors query in the location to fetch everything right upto the top and filter out based on the priority in python to create device outputs.

Thanks <@1082587798328061973> , this is more what profiles are for, but there's a part lacking to do exactly what you want, which is to assign relationships to profiles. I'll add you to this feature request, and post a link shortly. The idea is you'd have profiles defined for DNS servers for Global and Europe (for example) and nodes (like a switch) would inherit according to the location hierarchy and priority.

model is for infrastructure instances like DNS,Radius -servers that we have multiple of. but we would like to order them differently, based on there relation to a location for example a region,country, site. different regions have the same servers but in different order/priority. The "shim"-layer as suggested in the thread can solve this but it gets bloated and cumbersome to manage for all locations and variations, instead of a property on the peer.

Hi <@1082587798328061973> not quite clear on which part of this you're looking for an update on? Also, it would be very helpful to understand what you're trying to model, where you'd want to add a property to a node relationship?
Hi, we have a similar use-case, are there any updates on this? I guess we are interested if it is possible to add a property to the node relationship? (Believe this is possible in neo4j)
a visualisation/explanation by what you guys are doing here would be very much appreciated for the graph-n00bs among which I'm one. Tagging along, glad you're discussing it in public
make sense

I've thought about splitting, and it was my original design, but I realized that some actions are multiple as well, i.e. 
1. apply community
2. accept

it just made more sense to have them all in one relationship at that point. It also allowed me to reference multiple policy groups, and create a boolean to create a "default action group" that is applied at the end of the policy. When I split them, the schemas wasn't as definitive, I had a "policy_group" relationship that held from entries, and a "default_policy_group" that held the default actions. 

By not splitting them, I can have multi-layered policies that allow multiple next-entries, next-policy, accept, reject, etc. and still have a default policy entry, all using the same node type

yeah it's a little less "practical"  and surely not "graph oriented" enough.
the other way would be to accept splitting entries and action and have 2 groups with the wieght in it, i wonder how deep you would like to have people have different details on the entries for a given group
thank you! I will give that a try - I'll watch your PRs to see if you come up with something more elegant
makes sense - a little less manual entry friendly, but that's solid for automation

So :

policy -> policy element (with attribute weight) -> entries_group
I will look at that - a "shim layer" if you will

The only response i could come up right now, is to have an object, which would do the junction between entries groups and the policy, and will add the weight.

A bit like the VRRP Interfaces or OSPF Interfaces in the PR I mentioned.

Hey <@1133022375051542558> , sorry to resurrect an old thread. But I was curious if you had any insight. 

Routing policies definitely have an order of application - but the way Infrahub exposes graph databases, it doesn't have any concept of a list, or ordered list that I can find. The groups are great, and I could write the generators to have a giant if/elif of how to build those policies, but I'm trying to write this to be more flexible. 

At this time, I have a concept of a routing policy node, which has a relationship with multiple entry groups, whose members are individual entries. Entries are either a "from" or "action". They are both descended from a generic entry. I *could* modify the generic to the concept of a weight/order, **but** that destroys their flexibility. I'd like to have the order defined in the entry group, so that the entries can be re-used in other entry groups. 

The end goal here is that I have a community or a prefix list, etc that I can query to see where and if it's used in a policy, and that the entry "from prefix list : [192.168.0.0/24, 192.168.1.0/24]" is only defined once, but could be ordered differently in any number of routing policies. 

Am I looking at this the wrong way? Or is there a solution I'm missing?
I was planing to extend it in the incoming few weeks, so i am right there with you !

that's exactly what I'm trying to extend - those were a good start, but not flexible and detailed enough. I'm trying to model down to the policy statement and entries in those statements. Appreciate the help!
I didn't improve the routing policies from the peerming-manager example, but you may have some other inspiration around it in https://github.com/opsmill/schema-library/pull/32

embeds.title: Improve Routing by BeArchiTek 路 Pull Request #32 路 opsmill/schema-l...

messages.content:
the top level Group is  `CoreGroup` (which is a generic)

You can create a node (i.e RoutingGroup ?) which would inherited from CoreGroup
This way every object could be assigned to it via the "member_groups" relationships when they are part of the group.

For a relations to this group you can create a normal relation to it with the peer `RoutingGroup`

<@1133022375051542558> thanks! Is there an example in the docs or in a repo somewhere I could base that off of? I attempted to create one using the top level node `groups` in my schema file, but digging through the schema definition I couldn't find it

Hey <@1268206427810435166> 

It will be the latter, it will have a relation to the group choose on the relationships

I'm attempting to model routing policies. I found the example of the security policies, and the peering manager import policies, but I think there's a possibility for a more fleshed out and flexible solution. 

Is there a way to create relationships between nodes that aren't defined in by `peer`? Groups from `CoreGroup` looks like a potential solution, where I could create all the nodes, and add them as members of a new group, and reference the group, but would that create a relationship of 1:(all of the members of the group)? Or would that be a 1:(members of the groups I've selected) relationship

I apologize for stating this poorly - but there's some pretty amazing stuff that could be done here in SoT terms. I'm struggling a bit to fit this into how could work in Infrahub
